audio_description: Bismillah ir-Rahman ir-Rahim, Assalamu Alaikum. Welcome back to Crafted Kitchen, and today we are making Lucknowi Mutton Biryani.

audio_description: Every biryani is special in its own way, but this one is my favorite because I’m from Lucknow. Lucknowi biryani is prepared with great delicacy and finesse. So, watch the video till the end as I’ll be sharing all the fine details.

audio_description: Onions, coriander leaves, mint, tomatoes, lemon, green chilies, dried plums—oh no, none of these go into this biryani. Instead, we’ll use aromatic and flavorful spices prepared in two different ways. Some spices will be used whole.

audio_description: Lucknow is famous for its aromatic touch, which enhances the biryani’s flavor. One tablespoon black pepper adds not only flavor but a hint of heat. Add 6–7 green cardamoms for aroma, and 7–8 cloves, which are...

audio_description: Break a few pieces of cinnamon. All these whole spices will add both flavor and aroma. Now let’s move to the spices that we’ll grind coarsely: one tablespoon fennel, one tablespoon cumin, and 5–6 green cardamoms.

audio_description: And the finely ground spices will be added to the milk. A unique thing about this biryani is that it includes milk. Lucknowi biryani is presented in a special way and should not contain any whole spices. I’ve used medium-aged goat meat here.

audio_description: For one kilo of meat, I’ve taken one kilo of extra-long grain basmati rice, which I’ve washed thoroughly in running water and soaked for 30 minutes. Rinsing the rice multiple times to remove starch is a very important step.

audio_description: I’ll also be adding half a cup of pure ghee. Typically, only oil is used in restaurant biryani, but since this is homemade, it deserves something special. The oil is hot now, and I’m adding freshly ground ginger-garlic paste.

audio_description: Add the mutton and sauté it until the color changes and it loses its raw smell. Lucknow is in North India, so its cuisine is also known as Awadhi cuisine. Although we call it biryani, technically...

audio_description: ...it's a layered rice and meat dish with elements like milk, rice, and meat, which were easily available in old times. With a few unique spices, this biryani evolved. The meat is well sautéed now, so I’ll add one tablespoon red chili powder...

audio_description: For the dum (steam cooking), cook the biryani on medium-high heat for 10 minutes and then on low heat for 20 minutes. Lucknowi biryani is traditionally served with finely sliced onion laccha. You can also serve it with yogurt raita or a bowl of yakhni.

audio_description: So, you saw how easily this famous milk-based Lucknowi mutton biryani was prepared. A good biryani is one where the grains are separate. Always let it rest covered for 10 minutes before serving so the rice softens a bit.
